Define \( d = \gcd(a, b) \) and express \( a \) and \( b \) in terms of \( d \): \( a = dx \) and \( b = dy \) where \( x \) and \( y \) are coprime integers.
Substitute \( a = dx \) and \( b = dy \) into the equation \( \frac{a+1}{b} + \frac{b+1}{a} \) and simplify.
Analyze the condition under which \( \frac{a+1}{b} + \frac{b+1}{a} \) is an integer in terms of \( x \), \( y \), and \( d \).
Deduce the necessary conditions on \( x \) and \( y \) for \( \frac{a+1}{b} + \frac{b+1}{a} \) to remain an integer when \( d \) changes.
Investigate how changes in \( d \) affect \( a+b \mod d^2 \).
Find a relationship or pattern between \( x \), \( y \), and \( d \) based on \( a+b \mod d^2 \).
Generalize the findings to deduce all possible values of \( a+b \mod d^2 \) under the integer condition.
